question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Alice is 5 ft tall and Bob is 6 ft tall. At some instant they are both
walking towards a street lamp 15 ft high with Alice west of the lamp and
Bob east of the lamp. Suppose at this instant, Alice is walking at 4
ft/s and the distance between the tips of their shadows is decreasing at
11 ft/s.

Draw a clear diagram for the situation. Let x be the distance between
Alice and the lamp, and let y the distance between Bob and the lamp (you
may label other distances in your diagram as well).
sols:
Consider a 15ft tall lamp at the origin of a grid (so that everyone to
the right is a positive distance away and everyone to the left is a
negative distance away).

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math104Dec12Q5a-lamp.png}
\end{figure}

Let x be the distance that Alice is to the \textbf{left} of the lamp. We
know that she is 5ft tall (which is shorter than the lamp post). Next,
let y be the distance that Bob is to the \textbf{right} of the lamp. He
is 6ft tall and so he is also shorter than the lamp but slightly taller
than Alice.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math104Dec12Q5a-alice_and_bob.png}
\caption{Math104Dec12Q5a-alice and bob.png}
\end{figure}

Rays of light will shine from the lamp, touch Alice and Bob and
eventually reach the ground (forming a big triangle with the lamp and
ground). Label the distance between where the light hits the ground for
Alice and the lamp as C and for Bob, D.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math104Dec12Q5a-light.png}
\caption{Math104Dec12Q5a-light.png}
\end{figure}

With this notation then the length of Alice's shadow, for example,
should be C-x. To get a better understanding of how we could see the
geometry of the problem better and how to go about solving it, it is
often useful to simplify the diagram. To do this we will replace our
characters with sticks since their dimensions don't affect the problem
as far as we are concerned. An example of what a more
mathematically-ready diagram should look like is below:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH104Q5a2012.jpg}
\caption{MATH104Q5a2012.jpg}
\end{figure}

The distance between the tips of the shadows is C+D and since we know
this is decreasing at 11ft/s, we could write

\[\frac{d}{dt}(C+D)=-11.\]
hints:
Each person is walking towards the lamppost, one is to the left of it
and one is to the right. Where should we place the lamppost? Who is on
the left? Who is on the right?

We are given that the distance between the tips of the shadow is
decreasing. Consider labelling the distance of each person's shadow tip
to the lamp. What is the total length between the tips?
